the moves to ease some of the restrictions, the community resilience team continued to provide vital services.He said: ldquoMuch of the media focus over the past week has been on the re-opening of pubs and restaurants and with it the added concern that more people may be exposed to Covid- as a consequence."Clearly no one wants to see a negative outcome with a second wave of coronavirus cases causing ato stricter lockdown measures."Whilst the UK and Scottish Governments have relaxed lockdown rules, there has been no relaxation of the work of our willing team of volunteers who continue to help deliver shopping, collect prescriptions and are doing dog walks."When you consider that some of our volunteers are still working, their support and commitment is really admirable."A special mention needs to go to Prestonpans acting SPoC Allan Sneddon, who has continued to work during the crisis and has not only headed our resilience effort ndash Allan led from the front delivering meals, leaflets, shopping for elderly residents and doing the occasional dog walk."A huge amount of work is still going on at the Pennypit with a lot of people still accessing their pantry , which really goes to show the need for this."The Pennypit Trust are currentlylooking at plans for the future, with a view to keeping the pantry running and the possibility of extending current services to meet the nutritional needs of the elderly and vulnerable in the community.The Pennypit has also been organising activities for youngsters during the holidays to keep them active and exercising.Anyone who needs support from the Pennypit Trust should contact Lorna on   or email lornabellany@gmail.Jane Russellrsquos Sunday chicken dinners continue to provide fresh meals every weekend to more than  households across East Lothian and meals can be ordered on the grouprsquos Facebook page or on  .The community team gave a special mention this week to Jane Shepherd, Tesco Musselburghrsquos Community Food Champion, who assembled  crates of food provisions over the last week, and Scotmid which has provided daily food supplies throughout the past four months.Contact detailsContact the resilience team on   or at prestonpansresilience@gmailTranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneTRANENT Emergency Response Team will stand down next Fridayand released its plan for what people can dothey still need help or still wish to volunteer.Volunteers will, after this date, no longer be needed to provide support in the community such as assisting with shopping, prescriptions, dog walking and checking on vulnerable people, services they have provided continuously since March.It also means these services will no longer be available as part of the community resilience initiative.The teamrsquos Facebook Messenger service and emergency telephone number will also no longer be available at the end of the month.The resilience effort in Tranent and Elphinstone has been led by the local community council and overseen by member, and single point of contact, Mike Falconer.Mike has continuously provided updates to the volunteers on Facebook group lsquoTranent Emergency Response ndash Coronavirusrsquo.Mike said: ldquoI am sure that many of those volunteers will continue to help out but simply as good neighbours."If you or someone you know is having dficulty and requires help after that date, we will be publishing a list of services, contact details and information on [the Facebook] page, on the Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council Facebook page and on our noticeboard in the car park at Winton Place Lindores Drive."If you are interested in volunteering here or where in East Lothian, check out Volunteer East Lothian ."Take care, stay safe and hopefully we wonrsquot need to resume operations!"Thanks to all of the wonderful volunteers, the rest of the team and the generous donations of time, money and effort which you, the community, have given over the last few months. You have all been great!Meanwhile, Mike thanked volunteer Susan Coyle, who made about  fabric masks. Resilience volunteers distributed these masks last week.Mike said: ldquoSusan has probably been the busiest of our volunteers over the last few months ndash collecting shopping and prescriptions and checking on neighbours. Well done, you are a star!Susan was presented with a bouquet of flowers from David Forrest, chair of Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council, as a token of thanks.Contact detailsContact the resilience team on   or at tranentemergencyresponse@gmailOther resilience groups contact detailsAberladyIan Malcolm  Sam Robertson  www.facebook AberladyResilience-BoltonShena Jamieson   orshenajamieson@aolDirletonwww.dirletonresilience.orgEast SaltounBuffy Neilson   orbuffyneilson@yahooGfordJo Allen  chairgfordcc@gmailAdam White  adamjswhite@outlookWendy Ferguson  wendyferguson.wf@gmailThe Rev Aniko Schuetz Bradwell  anikoschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukLongniddrySheila Jamieson  Macmerry  Gladsmuir communityresilienceteam@gmailOrmiston OrmistonRCteam@hotmailWest SaltounDerek Smith  coruisk@gmail

title: bid-drive-thru-coffee-shop-eyesore-service-area
story: The Motor Fuel Group has applied to East Lothian Council for planning permission to build a coffee shop with drive-thru and create additional car parking.There would also be a new dedicated entrance to serve the adjacent Travelodge hotel.More than  jobs would be created as a result of the development.The hotel used to share an entrance with the now vacant Burger King and Little Chef restaurants, which closed several years ago.The site is located close to Old Craighall Roundabout which connects the A Edinburgh City Bypass to the A.North of the site is the B that connects to Monktonhall and then Musselburgh beyond, with the town centre .km from the service area.Tony Thomas, director of East Linton-based APT Planning and Development, said: ldquoThe plan is to demolish part of the original building complex that previously housed Burger King and Little Chef, and create a more dedicated and convenient car park for the Travelodge.ldquoOn the western part of the site we are proposing a drive-thru coffee outlet. Apart from that, the site will be landscaped and upgraded.He said that the current petrol station there, also owned by the Motor Fuel Company, would remain in use.Mr Thomas could not yet say which company would run the drive-thru coffee shop however, an image of the proposed outlet shows a logo for Starbucks.He said it was hoped the work would be completed within a yearplanning consent was granted.A landscape design report, submitted with the planning application, said the ldquoenhanced car park arrangement would provide nine accessible parking bays close to the building entrances and five electric car charging points.It added: ldquoWith the proposed coffee shop there is an opportunity to provide two areas of external seating ndash these have been carefully sited to maximise a south-facing aspect so that visitors can make the most of sunshine.ldquoBoth of these seating areas have plant beds located close by.ldquoThese beds will help to create a sense of enclosure."These plant beds will be planted with a iety of trees, shrubs and hardy perennial plants that will provide seasonal interest.ldquoThe plants will also help to screen any queuing cars into the drive-thru.ldquoTo the front of the retained Travelodge building, we have proposed another plant bed, planted with native trees ndash birch and rowan ndash and robust groundcover.ldquoElsewhere in the new car park, we have looked to punctuate the space with street trees these trees will help to provide vertical structure to the space.ldquoThe proposals look to retain the dense group of semi-mature trees to the west of the site.ldquoTo the north of the site there is a row of sycamore trees that will also be retained.ldquoWith the demolition of the building, there will be a gap in these trees and it is proposed that an additional four sycamore trees are planted to complete the row.ldquoThese trees will work as a buffer between the new car park and the road.ldquoTo make way for the development we are proposing to remove five small trees within the car park that have failed to establish.Other tree planting will take place around the site.Irene Tait, chair of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, welcomed the plan, saying: ldquoIt is an eyesore at the moment and something needed to be done for a while ndash as long as the landscaping fits in with the rest of the area.Ward councillor Stuart Currie, who is not a member of the councilrsquos planning committee, added: ldquoA big part of the site has been lying empty for some time and has become a real eyesore.ldquoThe entire site is already set up as a drive-thru facility alongside the hotel so, as long as itrsquos contained within the current boundary [Irsquom happy to support it].ldquoIt will create jobs and be brought back into full use from a boarded-up building.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothianrsquos MP, said: ldquoThere seems merit in it."Itrsquos a gap site and the facilities would enhance the area.ldquoAs long as it abides by any criteria set by council, the work and project seem welcome.

title: nurses-covid-19-efforts-win-hotel-stay-anywhere-world
story: Alison Williams, a research nurse at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, was nominated in the holiday competition by Rock My World Travel of North Berwick.The -year-old Edinburgh resident, who visited North Berwick on holidays as a child, has been branded a ldquosuperhero after raising more than pound, in her campaign to create lsquoRainbow Boxesrsquo for patients.The campaign started after Alison witnessed first-hand that several patients had few personal items as family members were unable to visit them, so did not have basic items such as pyjamas and toiletries.She said: ldquoA lot of people were being admitted in emergency situations so they didnrsquot have and were missing essential items, from nightwear to phone chargers.She added that other initiatives aimed to help nurses, whereas this specically helped patients.The mum of two, who studied at Napier University and qualied in , then came up with the idea to get these items to the patients and launched a campaign on a local Facebook group, Edinburgh Gossip Girls, with the original aim of raising pound to create the boxes.To date the total stands at more than pound,, with a further pound, donated from RBS, bringing the total raised to more than pound,.Alison said: ldquoThe pound target was smashed in a few minutes.She now has a small team of people supporting her.She added: ldquoWe have enough money to last until October but hopefully things will be back to normal [by then] and people can come in on visits and the need wonrsquot be as great.Boxes are delivered to all  wards in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, as well as nearby hospices and the East Lothian Community Hospital in Haddington.Her campaign, alongside her job as a nurse and working during the current coronavirus crisis, led to her being nominated in the holiday competition by Rock My World Travel.The competition was featured in Travel Weekly, a travel industry trade magazine, and run by travel company Stuba, in recognition of the hard work of local heroes who have emerged during the pandemic.People were in with a chance of winning a pound hotel voucher. Alison was one of  national winners.Isobel McCardie, who runs Rock My World Travel alongside her husband Mark, nominated Alison.Isobel, who lives in North Berwick, said: ldquoWhen I saw what Alison was doing, it instantly resonated with me.ldquoNot only was she on the frontline fighting Covid-, but her compassion for the patients inspired her to go further.ldquoAs soon as I saw the competition, I instantly thought of Alison. She has been completely selfless in this entire task and is working tirelessly, I canrsquot think of anyone who deserves a break more.On the nomination, Alison said: ldquoI only knew about it when she phoned me and told me Irsquod won. Itrsquos really nice that someone who doesnrsquot know me nominated me. Itrsquos amazing and flattering.Alison plans to take her colleague Rachel, who has been working tirelessly to help Alison with her campaign.When askedshe had decided where to go, Alison said: ldquoIrsquom not wanting to go too far. Irsquoll possibly go somewhere in Scotland.

title: alcohol-confiscated-youths-sent-back-midlothian
story: As the Covid- restrictions are slowly eased, policing and our response is ing to a more recognised model.This week we have reinstated our appointments system where we can again come to you at a convenient time that fits into your day, deal with your enquiry over the phone or attend immediately where required.Officers are slowly ing to their normal working locations with new social distancing measures implemented and calls we are attending are more like what I would expect at this time of year.Face masks, particularly on public transport and in shops, have been a hot topic and the current guidance is that they must be worn.Police officers in the exercise of their duty are exempt from this however, I have instructed that unless it is an emergency, my officers will wear face masks in shops and on transport.In my last few columns, I have commented on a rise in large groups of youths congregating and in some instances causing anti-social behaviour.Over the past few weeks I have had additional patrols and resources allocated to this and we have worked closely with East Lothian Council Safer Community Team.What we have found is that groups of youths have been coming down from Midlothian and engaging in disorder with some youths from East Lothian.At the weekend, my officers dealt with a large gathering of youths who were dispersed and got buses back up to Midlothian.Some youths were charged, alcohol was confiscated and others will receive a letter home addressed to their parents through our Parental Advisory Lettersystem.This early action prevented disorder occurring later in the day and we will continue to do this over the coming weeks.Our road and speed checks across the hotspot and coastal areas continue and we have contributed signicantly to the national summer drug drink driving campaign.Our licensed premises and restaurants re-opened in line with the Scottish Government guidance and I am really pleased to say that we had no incidents reported and everyone enjoyed themselves sensibly.The beaches and beauty spots continue to bring people from all over Scotland and, now with the English school holidays started, further afield.Last weekend I witnessed first-hand the fantastic work done by East Lothian Council employees to keep the areas safe and clean in very challenging circumstances.The next stage of lockdown is still a while away and I ask that you all continue to follow the current guidelines set to keep yourself and others safe.If you are getting a holiday, I hope it is a pleasant one and that you get good weather to enjoy it.

title: wildlife-diary-studying-kingfisher
story: Although Zan has always had an interest in photography, it was after moving to Scotland that she discovered a passion for wildle and now spends every spare moment pursuing that endeavour.This has led her to volunteering for multiple wildle charities, as well as studying for an MSc in Wildle, Biology and Conservation alongside her photography. In this monthly column, she shares her wildle diary ndash and pictures!DURING lockdown, I was trying to make the most of my free time ndash going on daily walks, working on my website, editing photos from before lockdown, designing my first book and completing A LOT of jigsaws .After the lockdown restrictions started to ease, I was able to spend even more time outdoors than I would normally do. I dedicated June to visiting dferent local sites to watch the kingfisher ndash which you may remember from my previous article ndash a family of wrens and the brown hares.One evening, as I was uploading my photographs on to social media and searching through the pages, I came across a few images of a bird that every birder wanted to see since its influx to the UK was published. It was a rosy starling!The beautul rosy starlinglooks nothing like the starlings we know. It strongly resembles a magpiewith a much shorter tail.This species is unmistakable in its adult plumage. The male has a pale pink body with a black head, wings, and tail. Additionally, during the breeding season the male develops a wispy crest and the black colour becomes glossier with a purplish green or blue sheen.The female is less vibrant than the male. Both sexes appear much duller outside of their breeding season.Furthermore, the rosy starling does not mimic other species, unlike its well-known cousin.What the two species have in common is murmuration ndash an astonishing and mesmerising aerial spectacle large flocks of these birds gather and perform a real show as they swoop, e and swirl across the sky in beautul shape-shting clouds. It is a phenomenon that pleases the eye of every observer.The rosy starlingrsquos breeding area stretches from the Balkans and Turkey to Central Asia and north-west China. It spends winters in India and south-east Arabia. As a strongly migratory species, it can travel outside of its normal breeding range. As a result, there are signicant periodic summer and autumn influxes in western Europe. The causes of such irruptions are not yet fully understood however, it appears to be related to changes in the population of locusts on which the birds feed.Imagine my amazement when I read that one of those birds had landed and made its temporary home in someonersquos garden in Port Seton!The cherry on the cake was that the night when I saw the first images of the rosy starling in East Lothian, I also received an email from Stuart Payne ndash the lucky host of the rosy starling. Stuart invited me to his garden.The next morning, my fianceacute Chris and I rushed to Port Seton. As we were walking towards Stuartrsquos house, we saw another birder looking around hoping to spot the rosy starling. As soon as we arrived at Stuartrsquos house, I saw this magnicent pink bird flying past the house and landing on the bird feeder to start its feast.Stuart and his we Gillian welcomed us in their garden, where I spent half an hour photographing the gorgeous rosy starling and chatting to Stuart and Gillian. I also took some time to admire their beautul dogs Hugo and Hobbes. These dogs were just wonderful, not every day you see dogs as well behaved as these two!My first and, I hope, not last experience with the rosy starling was unforgettable! I am incredibly grateful to Stuart and Gillian for reaching out to me and inviting me over. You wouldnrsquot be reading this article about the rosy starlingnot for the two of them!If there is any particular species yoursquod like to read about or have a rare visitor to your garden yoursquod like to share with me, donrsquot hesitate to get in touch through my website or social media channels.Speak to you next month!zanslensfacebook zanslensinstagram zans_lenstwitter zans_lens

title: pictures-prestonpans-lockdown-gala-day
story: Like many events in the county, the annual Prestonpans Childrenrsquos Gala was impacted by the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.The galarsquos organising committee had several discussions and, following advice from both East Lothian Council and the Scottish Government, it first postponed and then cancelled the gala day, which had been due to be held on June .However, the committee still wanted to recognise and mark the day.One suggestion was to give all of those in the royal court a goodie bag and rename the event, so instead it held what it called lsquoLockdown Gala Dayrsquo.Graeme Hutchison, gala convenor, told the Courier: ldquoThis was to encourage the kids and remind them that we hadnrsquot forgotten that this should have been their special day.ldquoThis idea kind of grew thanks to our chairperson Vikki Burns suggesting we could have an alternative gala day parade.The parade consisted of the gala committee members decorating their cars with balloons and bows in gala colours.They then travelled around Prestonpans, stopping at the houses of each member of the royal court to deliver them their goodie bag, honking their horns as they passed.Graeme said: ldquoIn the lead-up to gala day there was still a buzz about the town people were still showing their support by putting up their bunting and the parents of the royal court were being made aware we would be visiting. Nobody knew what to expect.ldquoGala day itself was amazing, from the glorious weather to the great response we got from the locals as we travelled around in convoy tooting and waving, visiting many streets of the town which the normal gala parade doesnrsquot visit. The people of Prestonpans certainly came out to show their support and for that we are truly grateful.ldquoWe would like to take this opportunity to thank the future Queen Lily [Bennion] and her royal court, as well as their families for their patience and understanding. Thanks to Connor from Sneddon Media for travelling with us and capturing the fantastic photos, which are on our Facebook page lsquoPrestonpans Gala Dayrsquo.ldquoFinally, thanks to the dedicated committee members who once again gave up their time to make the event possible.ldquoWe hope to be back doing some fundraisers in the not too distant future to help us fund and prepare as we look forward to Gala Day  on Saturday, June .After Lockdown Gala Day, Graeme took to social media to share his thoughts on the event.He said: ldquoPrestonpans, you didnrsquot disappoint us.ldquoThe fantastic efforts made from everyone to put up your bunting and decorate your streets, please repeat this next year. It was great to see so many of you as we travelled around as many streets as we could while visiting the members of the royal court.ldquoTo the royal court children, we didnrsquot want to forget that it would have been your day, we can still have your special day next year.ldquoTo Queen Lily, you were absolutely stunning, even reducing some of the committee to tears your mum and dad will be proud of you, the way you conducted yourself on what should have been your special day. To you, the community of Prestonpans for coming out and showing your appreciation as we passed by quietlyin our cars, doing the alternative gala parade. Hopefully you enjoyed it.He also thanked his fellow gala committee members for giving up their time and ensuring gala day traditions continued.

title: pop-up-cycle-lane-coastal-road
story: The local authority received pound.million from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Spaces for People fund to introduce measures to make it easier to social distance in town centres and improve cycle and pedestrian paths.And it has revealed that the next phase of work will involve establishing a temporary cycle lane between Prestonpans and Cockenzie, along the main road.It will also see the speed limit on the road, which is normally mph, reduced to mph and speed limits in the twocommunities reduced to just mph.The council has already received two strikes over its ambitious plans to transform its town centres this month, with u-turns made twice on projects.At the start of July it unveiled its plans, which included introducing parking suspensions across town centres as it looked to create more space outside shops and relocate parking away from high streets.In Haddington town centre there was a furious response after cones and parking suspension notices went up over the first weekend of the changes, leaving traders and their customers fuming.Shop owners who had only just opened their doors feared the restrictions would stop costumers fromcoming to the market town and within days the council announced it was putting parking suspensions in all town centres on hold.Then last week, it announced plans to transform tourist hotspot North Berwickrsquos town centre and create a temporary -space car park on its iconic Elcho Green ndash a much-loved publicspace and putting green.The response from the community, including Solheim Cup captain Catriona Matthew, who voiced concern at losing green space like the Green, saw those plans also shelved as the local authority insisted it was a ldquolistening council and would carry out further consultation.The latest plan for a three-metre-wide cycle lane between Prestonpans and Cockenziewill see dozens of painted stones created by local schoolchildren, which line the footpath, moved however, the council said it has agreed with the local community council for them to be collected and relocated across he road.Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesperson, said: ldquoWe received many comments in the public consultation around Spaces for People on the need to provide suitable space for people cycling.ldquoMany people are currently cycling this route and we need to cater for the current increase in cyclists during the Covid- pandemic period.ldquoIn common with other Spaces for People measures, this route is for temporary use as we gradually move out of restrictions and will also provide a viable alternative to the use of the private car and or public transport for shorter-distanced essential or leisure trips in the area.The works will also include the introduction of temporary crossings of Edinburgh Road at either end of the route through the use of lsquobuildoutsrsquo and bolt-down bollards.MrHampshire added: ldquoWe were aware of a collection of painted stones that have been carefully laid by local schoolchildren alongside the existing footway along Edinburgh Road and recognise that these are important to the local community.ldquoThe community council has arranged for these to be carefully collected prior to the start of the works and have been relocated on the other side of the road.

title: column-job-figures-worrying
story: Furloughing has worked but unemployment is creeping up.Keeping folk in work and creating new jobs through investment in necessary public works is essential.Whether broadband, new council housing or retrofitting older homes and schools, therersquos things that need done and willing hands to do them.Itrsquos another reason why itrsquos good to see cafes, pubs and restaurants reopening.People work in them, as well as customers welcoming the socialisation just as much as the food and drink on offer.It wonrsquot be easy for owners, as social distancing requirements make it awkward and necessary hygiene rules also impact.Itrsquos also the case that some just wonrsquot be able to reopen as theyrsquore just not able to meet the rules or make a living under them.Itrsquos why the Chancellor should extend the furlough, as in France and other countries, to support those businesses until they can.In the interim, as with this paperrsquos laudable campaign to shop local, we should all try and support local venues.Parliament this week again considered trade and proposed new deals with the USA and other countries.But as with unemployment, whatrsquos creeping out is frightening.I took part in a discussion hosted by Trade Justice International which had representatives from the NFU, RSPCA and other far from radical groups, all of whom expressed concern.Indeed, an NFU petition has gathered over one million signatures.Chlorinated chicken has dominated the headlines but whatrsquos becoming clear is thatrsquos not the least of the threats, repugnant enough as it is.The whole treatment of animals is done with little care for their welfare, let alone those that work in the sector or for consumers who buy the product.Cheap food imports are heralded by the Tory Government, but they come at a price thatrsquoll be paid by hard-working local farmers and all of us in what wersquore forced to eat.

title: column-much-enjoy-preston-seton-gosford
story: For many, foreign holidays have already passed or been cancelled, would be too expensive to book at this late stage, or they do not want to take either the health or financial risk of booking one. So the lure of the staycation has become attractive to many for the first time and, luckily being in East Lothian, we have plenty to keep us entertained.We have a huge number of attractions, whether that be our numerous world-renowned golf courses, the nationally recognised National Museum of Flight and Scottish Seabird Centre in North Berwick, or as one of Scotlandrsquos premier coastal destinations for food and drink.What always interests me is that there is so much available that not everyone knows everything. I am often struck by people not knowing some of the sites in my ward of Preston, Seton and Gosford. Therefore, I thought this week I would take the opportunity to plug them and encourage you to visit us.To start in the west of the ward in Prestonpans exists the Prestonpans Murals Trail, which is made of over  pieces of art, and depicts the townrsquos culture and history.This includes murals on its witch hunts, industrial past, the influence on famous conservationist John Muirrsquos early le, and relation with migration both to and from Scotland ndash well worth a few hoursrsquo walk around the town.Also in the town there is the unappreciated Preston Tower, a structure with parts still standing from the th century. It is a one-of-a-kind building, with dferent parts and floors having been added over the years and other bits destroyed since it was first built.Currently it isnrsquot open but Prestonpans Community Council has been pushing to get it in a fit state so that the people of Prestonpans can truly benefit from this one-of-a-kind building.Moving east into Cockenzie and Port Seton, next to the harbour is the  Waggonway Museum. It is a fantastic museum and project that tells the story of the arearsquos extensive industrial history, including of the Tranent-Cockenzie Waggonway, built in  and associated with the coal and salt industries.Nearby sits Cockenzie House, a mansion and gardens dating from the th century. It is now home to a brilliant wee cafe and numerous craft businesses well worth a visit.In between Longniddry and Port Seton sits Seton Colligate Church, considered ldquoone of the finest medieval collegiate churches in Scotland. It was built in the late s by landowner Lord Seton so the community of priests could pray for his familyrsquos salvation.Finally on the coast there is Longniddry Bents, East Lothian largest tourist attraction. It is a beautul stretch of coastline home to a large iety of wildle, including many types of birds, voles and seals.Soyou are having a staycation this summer, visit the Preston, Seton and Gosford area and, whilst here, support our local cafes, shops, restaurants and pubs.

title: letter-it-act-vandalism
story: Today we are faced with a proposal to turn part of one of these beautul natural sites, in a designated conservation area, into an unsightly car park.Having been born and brought up in North Berwick and able to take advantage of the foresight of our forefathers, I was astonished to find not only that the proposal had been lsquoapprovedrsquo, but that it had been made at all. This is a vulnerable site and the suggestion of lsquotemporaryrsquo use is no guarantee.I am well aware of the problems of parking in our commercially vibrant High Street and all the efforts made over the years to come up with a solution.But parking cars on Elcho Green, a uniquely placed recreational facility for young and old, is not one of them. It would be an act of vandalism comparable with covering the gravestones in the old graveyard, which from a parking point of view would be even more convenient.George Finlayson CMG CVOCraigleith ViewNorth Berwick

title: tims-tales-little-red-riding-hood-wee-rud
story: THERE wis yince a young lassie carsquod Wee Rud. She wis carsquod Wee Rud cause whenever she gaed oot, she wore a rud hoodie. So her pals gied her that nickname, ater the story aboot Wee Rud Riding Hood.Wee Rud hud missed her grandma awfy much durin the lockdoon. She hud spoken tae her oan the computer, but that wasnae the same. Shersquod missed her hugs and the smell orsquo soup in her hoose.Sae when the lockdoon wis being lted, Wee Rud asked her mither: ldquoCan I gang tae grandmarsquos noo Her mither smiled. She understood how hard it hud bin: ldquoAye darlin, yer allowed noo, she will huv missed ye tae.Wee Rud jumped up n doon in wi joy. She packed a basket fu orsquo cakes she hud learnt tae bake during the lockdoon, and gied her ma a wee cheerio kiss.ldquoDinnae forget, gang straight tae grandmarsquos hoose, her mither said. ldquoDinnae footer aboot alang the way and mind no tae talk tae ony wolves.ldquoAye, dinnae worry ma, said Wee Rud, ldquoIrsquoll be carefu I ken the rules.Wee Rud wis a clever lass. She kent a wolf hud been hangin aboot, following folk an eatin grandmas. It wis a gye sleekit creature, it kent how tae hide and trick ye. But Wee Rud wis mair clever, she kent how tae keep safe frae it.She saw the wolf but she wisnae scared. She kept her distance and gied him a wee smirk as she went oan her way tae her grandmarsquos hoose.Wee Rud knocked oan her grandmarsquos door and gaed in. ldquoGranny itrsquos me! Wee Rud! Irsquove brought ye some cakes. I baked them masel.Her grandma stairted tae greet. They were tears orsquo joy, not sorrow, fir she hud missed her beloved Wee Rud sae much. They hugged sae tight their een near popped oot!ldquoYe gang ben the hoose wi thae cakes an Irsquoll put oan a cup orsquo tea, and wersquoll have a richt guid blether, said grandma.While Wee Rud wis putting the cakes oan the coffee table, her grandma came wi the tea. Wee Rud telt her grandma that she hud seen the wolf skulking aboot, but that shersquod flung him a deefie.ldquoGuid lass, said Grandma, ldquothat wolf is a richt sleekit creature, but noo that we ken his tricks we can change the story. They baith laughed.But the wolf wisnae laughing, he wis angry. It couldnae get intae the hoose tae eat grandma. Wee Rud hud bin tae clever.Ater huvin a braw time wi her gran, Wee Rud gied her another hug and left fir hame.Wee Rud arrived back at her hoose wi a happy shine oan her face. ldquoIt wis sae nice tae see Grandma, she said tae her mither.But the wolf wasnae happy in fact he wis ragin. ldquoThis isnae how the story is supposed tae be, he said tae himself, ldquoshersquos supposed tae break the rules and I get intae her grandmarsquos hoose and eat her.Just then, twa nurses were passin by oan their way tae work and heard whit the wolf said.ldquoAye weel, that lassie wis wise tae ye, and so are we, they said.They picked up a stick and waved it in the air, and the wolf ran away.Noo it wis the wolf that wis feart.It looked for ither folk tae follow but noo people kent its tricks and sae it didnae hae much orsquo a chance tae eat grannies onymair.The story hud been changed by Wee Rud, and she hud a wee laugh every time she thocht aboot it.And her grandma wis richt pleased she hudnae been scoffed by the wolf, thanks tae the wisdom orsquo her granddaughter.

title: coronavirus-poll-scots-support-another-lockdown-second-wave-occurs
story: In the study carried out by YouGov, % of people ldquostrongly support the idea of full measures being introduced in the event of a second wave, with a further % ldquosomewhat supportive of the idea.Meanwhile just under one in tenof Scots would ldquostrongly oppose the second lockdown, with another % ldquosomewhat opposing the idea.The remaining % of the responded as ldquodonrsquot know.The YouGov poll surveyed  adults.It comes as figures in Scotland revealed there had been no deaths of people who tested positive for the virus recorded in the past week ndash meaning the toll remains at  ndash and only one in the past  days.The First Minister described this as the ldquoincredible progress made since the country went into lockdown.In the last few weeks Scots have been able to enjoy more freedoms, including the reopening of pubs, restaurants and the tourism sector.Another YouGov poll of the same number of adults revealed that % of people in Scotland would not have a coronavirus vaccine when it became available.The vast majority ndash around %, said they would take the vaccine, with a further % responding as ldquodonrsquot know.

title: midge-repellents-top-tips-keep-scotlands-biting-beasties-bay
story: The dreaded midge isnt to be trled with. Weve all been there, sitting outside on a warm summers evening and enjoying a sunset, when there comes a tell-tale nip upon exposed flesh. The arm, the leg, the neck, the face, the scalp ndash the midge isnt fussy ndash and before you know it, youre under siege.With more of us set to enjoy staycations this year, we need to learn to coexist with these tiny flying brutes, which is why Im offering up my services as a human guinea pig. Im a good test subject given Ive never met a midge that doesnt like me.I still bear the scars ndash mental and physical ndash of a long weekend in Glen Coe a few years ago. It was July. There was cloud cover, no wind and a sticky humidity. I was almost eaten alive.Scotlands walks are never complete without the dreaded midgeBelieve me, I have tried everything to keep the midges at bay. Among the long list of suggestions that Ive given a whirl are eating Marmite sandwiches, spraying a fine mist of Listerine and taking garlic tablets .Smoke can act as a deterrent, which has seen me huddling next to barbecues and bonfires like they are two-bar electric fires on cold winter mornings.Ive donned midge nets that give me the forlorn air of a beekeeper who has lost her hive, or a grieving Victorian widow. Im considering putting up bat boxes after reading that a lone bat can eat , midges in one night.Citronella and Saltidinare among the ingredients that midges are said to find repugnant and give a wide berth. Essential oils such as eucalyptus, lavender and lemongrass have been credited with similar properties .The midge has a mighty reputation for such a miniscule insect. Weighing just one th of a gram, it has a teeny wingspan of -mm. Midges breed in vast numbers across  per cent of Scotlands land mass.Midges are said to enjoy the smell of our natural body odour and sweat which is where using certain scents can come in handy.Avon Skin So Soft , pound.This moisturiser wasnt designed with midges in mind but has famously been adopted for that purpose. When I interviewed the ultramarathon runner Dean Karnazes in , he mentioned that a friend had advised stocking up on Avon Skin So Soft would be prudent before a visit to Scotland.The Royal Marines are said to swear by its midge-repelling powers when training or based in and around the west coast.The secret to Skin So Soft creating a no-fly zone for midges has been widely attributed to the citronella that it contains.Skin So Soft has been my go-to over the years, clocking up a decent midge-busting hit rate.Application consistency: A dry oil spray.Smell: Baby talcum powder.Verdict: Still a classic. It has won an army of global fans for good reason.Visit avon.ukSmidge , pound.Wandering around shops and supermarkets across the Highlands during the summer months, you will see tourists clutching this elixir.Smidge has been about for a decade now. Its development was led by Dundee-based Dr Alison Blackwell, an authority on midge behaviour and leader of the team behind the Scottish Midge Forecast.The active ingredient is Saltidin which, according to the blurb, "has been molecularly designed to effectively block the antennal receptors of biting insects ndash basically, it throws them off your scent." Smidge is also billed as working on mosquitoes, black flies, sand flies, fleas and ticks.Application consistency: A lightweight, aluminium cannister with pump spray that dispels a fast-absorbing, water-based lotion.Smell: Chic unisex scent. Think CK One.Verdict: Did a stellar job as I sat in my tree-covered garden on a still, humid evening.Visit smidgeupMary Jean Highland Midge Lotion , poundThe idea of making a midge lotion is one that Elizabeth and Mary Quinn struck upon by chance. The owners of family-run Mary Jean in Fochabers, Moray, were selling their skincare products at a Highland Games in .The midges were biting and in a moment of inspiration, Mary soaked some kitchen roll in lemongrass oil and hung it from their stall. It worked a treat and an idea took seed, leading to the creation of Mary Jean Highland Midge Lotion.Ingredients include lemongrass ndash of course ndash as well as bog myrtle, aloe vera, jojoba, neem and mango. It is a wholesome product: handmade, organic, palm oil-free, vegan-friendly and non-toxic. Available in a ml travel size. Can also be used to deter mosquitoes and horseflies.Application consistency: A luxurious and light-feeling cream from a pump dispenser.Smell: Delicious citrus overtones.Verdict: A brilliant product that kept me midge-free. It also helped soothe redness on existing bites.Visit maryjeanAnderson Aromatics Beastie Be Gone , poundBeastie Be Gone, which launched in May, was coined by Bothwell-based clinical aromatherapist and perfumer Julie Anderson-McKee.As someone who loves the outdoors ndash Anderson-McKee can often be found camping in a tent or a caravan by a loch ndash she knows only too well the blight of midges.The result is a triple action cream that combines insect repellent, SPF  protection and a moisturiser that can be used as an after sun. It comes with excellent credentials, including being vegan, hypo-allergenic and as Anderson-McKee puts it "free from all nasties".Tried and tested by  Scottish wild campers and walkers, among the ingredients are organic shea butter, coconut and almond oils, lavender, lemon eucalyptus, citronella and myrrh.Application consistency: A sumptuous cream in a sleek metal container.Smell: Pleasant hints of lemon and lavender.Verdict: An impressive new kid on the block that does what it says on the tin.Visit andersonaromatics

title: scotlands-schools-four-key-updates-parents-ahead-reopening
story: Primary and secondary schools across the country closed their doors back in March to all but a few children.But with coronavirus in Scotland being suppressed to very low levels, things are employ hundreds of teachers and support staff to help schools re-open.An extra poundmillion was also pledged to cover other health protection costs.The funding will equate to around  teachers and  support staff.But as Labourrsquos education spokesperson, Iain Gray, pointed out, that accounts for only half a new member of staff per school across Scotland.August   Councils and schools have been working to the August date for some time.But the Scottish Government will not formally announce the August date until July .The Scottish Government has repeatedly stressed that reducing the infection rate is crucial to the reopening of schools, with the First Minister earlier in the week suggesting no more lockdown changes will be made until pupils are back in the classroom.Mr Swinney stressed that in Scotland, the infection rate is ldquoreducing by  per cent each week, but a sudden surge in cases over the next few weeks could sht the Scottish Governmentrsquos confidence that it is safe to ndash but some questions still remain over how this will work in practice.While primary pupils will not have to socially distance when theyon August , all being well, secondary schools will be told to title: face-masks-scotland-two-key-mistakes-everyone-making
story: So far, just one person has been handed a pound fine for not complying with the rules ndash as the country tries to further control the suppression of the coronavirus.The Scottish Government say that in enclosed spaces, where physical distancing is more dficult with people who are not members of your household, you should wear a face covering.By law, you must wear a covering in shops and on public transport ndash with similar rules coming into force in England today.But there are some parts of the guidance that many people seem to be forgetting.They are:Who Is exempt from wearing a covering Some people are not required to wear a face covering.These include:You are required by law to wear a face covering in Scotlands shops and on public transport .Find out how you can #StaySafe and protect others ##You may also have a reasonable excuse not to wear a face covering , for example:Inidual discretion should be applied in considering the use of face coverings for other children including, for example, children with breathing dficulties and disabled children who would struggle to wear a face covering.

title: 13-unusual-quirky-places-holiday-scotland
story: With the nationrsquos tourism sector now reopened, wersquove put together a list of some of our favourite awe-inspiring holiday accommodation.Places that bring together architectural wizardry and painstaking refurbishment to breathe new le ndash and use ndash into everything from a lighthouse to a modern-day broch and erstwhile modes of transportation, including buses, train carriages and even a helicopter.Roulotte Retreat, near Melrose, Scottish BordersThere is something wonderfully romantic about this circle of seven colourful roulotteslocated in a pretty wildflower meadow below the Eildon Hills.Each roulotte faces onto a lochan at the centre of the site. Facilities include sunset decks, wood-burning stoves, eco saunas and hot tubs. Itrsquos a perfect getaway for nature lovers with owls, deer, foxes, and badgers among the regular visitors.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit roulotteretreatHelicopter Glamping, Mains Farm Wigwams, Thornhill, StirlingStay in a Sea King helicopter complete with mini kitchen, bathroom and a cockpit seating area offering stunning views over the Forth Valley. The helicopter ndash part of Mains Farm Wigwams ndash sleeps two adults or a family of five . Therersquos a double bed, a single bed in the tail and seating which converts into a second double bed. The owners are currently renovating a  Scottish Aviation Twin Pioneer plane set to open for overnight stays next year.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit mainsfarmwigwamsSleeperzzz, Rogart, SutherlandChoose between a vintage railway carriage, a freight wagon or the Waiting Room BB.Located beside a ing train station at Rogart , Sleeperzzz offers budget accommodation for backpackers, families, walkers, cyclists or those who simply fancy spending the night somewhere a bit dferent ndash such as a -ton goods van from the s.A great base for exploring Dunrobin Castle and the North Coast .Prices from poundpp per night. Call   or visit sleeperzzzCraighead Howfs, Dunblane, PerthshireBe transported to The Shire ndash which could be Perthshire or JRR Tolkienrsquos fictional Middle-earth in The Lord of the Rings, depending on how you look at it ndash with these magical Hobbit Howfs.The Burrow and Bagend are built into the hillside with grassy roofs and round doors for an unforgettable glamping experience. Craighead Howfs also offers the chance to stay in a treehouse with panoramic views over the Ochils and a secluded summer house.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit craigheadhowfThe Bus Stop, Gford, East LothianIf you have ever wanted to enjoy a Summer Holiday in the vein of the  film, look no further. This fleet of buses in a field belonging to an arable farm in East Lothian have been transformed into holiday accommodation with armchairs, sofas, lanterns, hot flasks, log stoves and beds.Each bus has a private wood-fired hot tub and barbecue fire pit. Choose from rustic or luxury ndash the latter have en suite bathrooms and swish mod cons. Oh, and therersquos gorgeous views of the Lammermuir Hills.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit thebusstop.scotBrockloch Eco Retreat, Kirkpatrick Durham, Castle DouglasFeatured on George Clarkersquos Amazing Spaces, Brockloch Eco Retreat is small but perfectly formed. Located on a working farm, therersquos two units: a contemporary, off-grid, micro-timber bothy facing into an open field and an incredible treehouse hideaway within a bluebell wood where the closest neighbours are red squirrels.The treehouse has a built-in double bed with a skylight to gaze at the treetops and stars as you drt off to sleep. This part of the world is a great place to see red kites.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit brocklochBlack Isle Yurts, Eathie Hill, RosemarkieSet in private woodland, all of the yurts within this eco-sensitive, wild-glamping site are based on designs used by nomadic people in Central Asia for thousands of years.In keeping with the Scottish climate, the traditional felt outer shell has been replaced with a waterproof canvas and therersquos a wood-burning stove to stay cosy on cooler nights. The site is a short drive from Chanonry Point which is fantastic for dolphin spotting.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit blackisleyurtsRua Reidh Lighthouse, near Gairloch, Wester RossBuilt in  by David Alan Stevenson, a cousin of the writer Robert Louis Stevenson and one of the famous ldquoLighthouse Stevensons, this beautul, remote location offers BB and self-catering, the latter in the charmingly named First Officerrsquos Quarters.Endless views, a glorious stretch of coastline, abundant bird and sea le, tranquillity, solitude and the thrill of potentially catching a glimpse of the Aurora Borealis on dark, starry nights awaits.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit stayatalighthouseCalgary, MullNot to be confused with the skyscraper-filled city in Alberta, this little corner of Mull is a delight.A byre, hayloft and dovecote are among the self-catering properties available at Calgary, each with its own distinctive character. Calgary also has an excellent cafe, art gallery and a woodland sculpture walk.Therersquos a beach within strolling distance where Robinrsquos Boat sells Isle of Mull ice cream. Sea eagles, otters and basking sharks can all be seen nearby.Prices start from pound for a seven-night stay. Call   or visit calgaryThe Scriptorium Apartments at St Benedictrsquos Abbey, Fort AugustusThe Scriptorium ndash the once secret writing room of the monastery ndash has two one-bedroom apartments with vaulted ceilings, gothic archways and stained-glass windows. Therersquos plenty to do in the grounds and gardens, be it tennis, badminton, croquet or giant chess. The former Monksrsquo Refectory has been converted into a Club Lounge and a chapel refurbished to incorporate a heated pool, sauna and steam room.Prices start from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit parrandierThe Brochs of Coigach, near Achiltibuie, UllapoolBrochs are an ancient dwelling found only in Scotland, dating back to BC. Gille Buidhersquos Broch and Scalrsquos Broch are a bit younger than thatand beautully enchanting structures.If you love upcycling, they will impress, built using stones from old, crumbling walls on nearby land and timber recovered from a dilapidated Victorian pier. Call   or visit thefoursistersThe Sawmill at Glen Dye, Banchory, AberdeenshireTalk about enjoying the great outdoors in style. Stay in a sleek, refurbished s Airstream Safari caravan in a small pine wood beside the fast flowing lade of a sawmill.A rustic, wooden seed store with roots back to the s serves as the kitchen, dining and sitting room. There are games, books, a record player and a memorable barbecue spot. Glen Dye also offers a river cabin, a bothy and two steading cottages, as well as running residential courses in crafts and wild food.Prices start from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit glendyecabinsandcottages
